subject: Newsquawk US Market Wrap - 6th December 2019: OPEC to cut deeper; US payrolls beats
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • SNAPSHOT: Equities higher, Treasuries down, USD higher, crude higher.
  • REAR VIEW: OPEC+ agrees deeper cuts; NFP beats expectations, consumer confidence rises; Canadian jobs report misses. 
  • COMING UP: SUN: Japan Q3 GDP. MON: Canada November housing starts/building permits. TUE: China CPI/PPI; UK Oct Manufacturing Production; Germany Dec ZEW. WED: US Nov CPI; FOMC rate decision/forecasts; BCB rate decision; US Nov Budget Balance. THU: UK General Election; ECB; SNB; CBRT; German Nov CPI (Final); Japan Q4 Tankan Survey. FRI: CBR; US Nov retail sales, Oct Business Inventories, Export/Import prices. Click here to  access our Week In Focus preview; click here for our central bank weekly briefing.

* US JOBS REPORT (NOV): The November employment situation report saw the main metrics surprise to the upside, with 266k nonfarm payrolls added to the US economy, eclipsing the forecast for 180k, as 40k GM workers returned back to work after industrial action; the headline beat pushed up recent averages (3-month 205k vs. prev. 176k, 6-month 196k vs prev. 156k, 12-month 184k vs. prev. 174k). Meanwhile, the jobless rate ticked down by one-tenth to 3.5% and the U-6 measure declined by the same margin to 6.9% (both likely as the participation rate slipped by one-tenth, taking it to 63.2%); wages grew by 0.2% M/M, short of the 0.3% M/M expectation, though the Y/Y metric rose to 3.1% from 3.0%. However, analysts generally seem cautious in revising their view that payroll growth is losing momentum; Oxford Economics, looking to 2020, sees the labour market being constrained by global headwinds, trade tensions, slower energy activity and cooling domestic demand. "A cooler employment trend should lead to a gentle glide in disposable income growth and consumer spending, but elevated personal savings, low interest rates, moderate inflation and healthy confidence levels should prevent a hard landing," and its economists believe wage growth will plateau around 3.0% as businesses continue to face cooling demand, tighter profit margins and limited pricing power. In terms of the implications for monetary policy, analysts say the report is not likely to result in any material reassessment of its outlook ahead of next week's FOMC. "As such," Oxford Economics writes, "we see the Fed staying 'on hold' for now, however, factoring our sub-potential GDP growth forecast at 1.6% in 2020, and our expectation for a persistent undershoot of the Fed's 2% inflation target, we foresee a Fed rate cut in March 2020."

* WTI FUTURES (F0) SETTLES 0.77 HIGHER AT USD 59.20; BRENT (G0) SETTLES USD 1.00 HIGHER AT USD 64.39: Crude markets were buoyed by the news that OPEC+ agreed to cuts of 496k BPD starting from Q1 2020, with an extraordinary meeting on March 5th-6th for a review, in line with JMMC recommendations on Thursday (click here for the specific production numbers).  The Saudi’s will continue with 400k bpd in voluntary cuts, on top of the additional 167k bpd in cuts they agreed to absorb at the latest OPEC+ meeting. The announcement was contrary to reports Thursday that Saudi was threatening to end additional voluntary cuts out of frustration with members of the cartel who have not been fully complying with quotas, there had been some concerns that, although roughly 500k bpd in additional cuts were known to have been agreed by OPEC+, this may have been offset by the Saudis ending or unwinding voluntary cuts. The kingdom did however caution that this would be on the condition of “everyone complying”. Russia, who was known to oppose additional output cuts heading into the meeting, accepted the agreement despite being unhappy with the proposed production quotas. The Russians did however demand it be able to exclude some 800k bpd in gas condensate production from output quotas, as will other non-OPEC members. Analysts have flagged however that such a concession to the Russians may trigger problems within the cartel down the line, indeed, the Nigerians have made similar request in the past and been rebuffed. Following the meeting Saudi Prince Abdulaziz bin Salman stated the target was 2.1mln BPD below the peak rates from last year’s meeting. Citi highlights that although this seems massive, it is important to note the market ran a 1.9mln BPD surplus in Q4 2018 on what amounted to OPEC+ oversupply. And notes US production has grown about 1mln BPD since October 2018. In terms of the price action, the news of continued Saudi over compliance sent WTI and Brent front month contracts as high as USD 59.85/bbl and USD 64.88/bbl respectively, levels not seen since the aftermath of the Saudi Arabian facilities in September.

* US/CHINA: China is to implement tariff waivers for some purchases of soybeans and pork from the US, which NEC Director Kudlow noted as “good mood music”. During Kudlow’s remarks, he reiterated language heard from other officials previously in the week, noting a China deal is still close, and US president Trump will demand a good deal with China noting talks have been constructive and “we are in fact close”. On the implementation of 15th December tariffs, he highlighted this is up to US President Trump, reiterating there are no arbitrary deadlines in talks between US and China, but stated the 15th December is a very important date. Kudlow also emphasised that the US will not tolerate intellectual property theft from any country. Elsewhere, China has reportedly taken countermeasures against US limit on diplomats, although details were slim.

* US UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN (DEC, PRELIM): Headline consumer sentiment ticked up by more than expected, printing 99.2 against an expected 97.0 from 96.8 prior. Pantheon Macroeconomics notes that most of the increase is in the current conditions component (+3.6 points to 115.2), which that sub-index tending to track jobless claims, and often takes cues from the stock market performance; meanwhile, expectations also rose --"both measures are slightly below their cyclical peaks but are very high by historical standards; the underlying trends seems broadly stable," Pantheon said, adding "spending growth, however, is undershooting compared to sentiment; ultimately, cashflow is more important." Finally, the inflation metrics dipped slightly (1-year to 2.4% from 2.5%; 5-year to 2.3% from 2.5%), suggesting little hit from the tariffs on consumer goods so far (tariffs took effective on 1st September).

* CANADA JOBS REPORT (NOV): The Canada jobs report was a negative surprise, seeing employment declining by 71.2k in November (expected +10k; full-time -38.4k vs. prev. -16.1k, part-time -32.8k vs. prev. 14.3k). The jobless rate ticked up to 5.9% from 5.5% (largest monthly rise since 2009), though wage growth rose slightly (4.40% Y/Y vs. prev. 4.36%). "A long string of earlier improvements in the normally highly volatile Canadian labour market data meant we were likely due for a significant downside surprise at some point - but the softening in November is nonetheless eye-catching," RBC wrote, "employment is still up (a likely above-trend) 26k per month in 2019 to-date given earlier gains, and with most of that coming from full-time work." RBC notes that part of the headline decline in November was due to a retracement of a public administration jobs boost in October, related to the federal election. RBC says that the silver lining, however, was the wage growth metric, which is holding up well despite slower jobs growth.

* T-NOTE (H0) SETTLED 13+ TICKS LOWER AT 128-28+: Yields are higher between 4-5bps across the curve, the the TPLEX seeing selling pressure in wake of a solid jobs report for November, where the headline surprised to the upside. Additionally, prelim consumer confidence data from the UoM was firmer than expected. Next week, the Fed is expected to stand pat on rates, and according to market pricing, as derrived from the CME's Fedwatch tool, there is a 100% chance of an unchanged decision (which was priced with 99.3% certainty on Thursday). Ahead of the US day, constructive news on the trade front (China plans to implement tariff waivers for some purchases of US ags, and will begin applications for importing soybeans and pork from the US) resulted in some downside for Treasuries. There was also reports of short-covering after remarks from NEC director Kudlow (tariffs are up to the President), while other reports suggested short-covering came ahead of next week's FOMC and ECB confabs. Major curve spreads, however, are little changed, though 2s5s and 2s10s are up by around 1bps at settlement, and 2s30s 5s10s 5s30s and 10s30s a touch narrower).

* CLOSING LEVELS: SPX +0.9% at 3,145.90; Dow +1.2% at 28,009.83; NDX +1.1% at 8,397.39; SECTORS: energy +2.00%, materials +1.02%, industrials +1.20%, consumer discretionary +0.80%, consumer staples +0.37%, health care +0.62%, financials 1.35%, IT +1.12%, telecoms +0.63%, utilities -0.22%.

* STOCK SPECIFICS: Amazon (AMZN) saw some slight downside after WSJ reported US President Trump was considering adding the company’s foreign sites to a notorious market list, which is a list of global marketplaces known for counterfeit goods. Goldman Sachs (GS) caught a bid after reports its 1Malaysia Development Bhd (1MDB) fine is likely to be under USD 2bln, a sum lower than what some analysts suggested the bank would have to pay for allegedly misleading investors over bond sales totalling USD 6.5bln that the bank helped raise for the sovereign wealth fund (1MDB). Tesla (TSLA) up just shy of 2% after China made Tesla cars qualify for subsidies where buyers will get as much as USD 3550 from the government. Uber (UBER) traded in the red after it released its statistics which saw 3000 sexual assault claims last year and in total it saw 107 total fatalities. Its sexual assault statistics showed one in 2mln trips saw non-consensual kissing of a non-sexual body part, where 1 in 3mln saw non-consensual kissing of a sexual body part. DR Horton (DHI) traded lower after a sell initiation from Goldman Sachs with a USD 51 price target and Ciena (CIEN) were lower by over 4% after a downgrade to sell from neutral at UBS.

* EARNINGS: Ulta Beauty (ULTA) surged over 10% following a strong earnings report which saw EPS beat plus a guidance update above analyst expectations. The cosmetics company also reported SSS for November +3.2%, Q3 SSS were up 7.8%. DocuSign (DOCU) traded 8% higher following its earnings where it beat on top and bottom line estimates and raised its FY20 forecasts higher than the street expectations. Cloudera (CLDR) also saw similar games after EPS and revenue beats whilst also providing better than expected guidance.

* WEEKLY FX WRAP – DXY: Overall poised to end the session with weekly losses but demonstrates a decent recovery on Friday heading into the end of the EU week amid a stellar US jobs report. Headline NFP printed at 266k, trouncing forecasts of 186k (prior revised higher to 156k from 128k), unemployment rate ticked to a 50-year year low of 3.5% from 3.6% and Nov average hourly earnings YY at 3.1% vs. 3.0% expectations. DXY looks to snap its 6-day losing streak which was induced by a string of recent downbeat data – earlier in the week, ISM manufacturing disappointed and breakdowns were bleak, ADP employment change and ISM non-manufacturing also printed sub-par. Meanwhile on the trade front and earlier the week, US President Trump showed no sense of urgency regarding a trade deal with China and stated that it may be better to wait until after the November 2020 US election. Despite this, unnamed sources pointed to progress in talks despite the heated rhetoric between the two nations. DXY heads into the end of the EU close towards the bottom of its 97.36-98.38 intra-week range, below its 100 DMA (98.13), 21 DMA (98.04), 100 WMA (97.98) and 200 DMA (97.65) - but off lows. Looking ahead to next week, the docket sees US CPI, retail sales and the FOMC monetary policy decision.

* CAD: A relatively mixed week for the Loonie with initial strength mid-week emanating from the BoC’s hawkish hold coupled with a more upbeat domestic and global economic assessment and with little in the way of a dovish pushback. Further, BoC’s Deputy Governor Lane added to the optimistic Canadian mood after noting that developments in recent weeks have given the Central Bank more confidence in its October outlook for growth and inflation. Anther CAD-supporting factors throughout the week included a surge in energy prices amid the backdrop of the OPEC+ congregation. That said, Friday’s dismal Canadian labour market report, coupled with US’ glowing data, saw USD/CAD reverse almost all of it recent losses. USD/CAD is poised to end the EU week modestly in the red but back above its 21 WMA (1.3215) and 100 DMA (1.3228), having traded within an impressive 1.3158-3321 weekly range, with the pair re-eyeing its 21 DMA (1.3257) and 200 DMA (1.3278) to the upside.

* GBP, EUR: An upbeat week for the Sterling and the Single currency, more-so the former amid early-week impetus and sustained gains from the latest UK general election Kantar poll, which showed a modest widening in the Tory/Labour spread, leading to short covering and stop tripping as Cable advanced above key figures, with further polls during the week (Savana/ComRes) showing the lead maintained as election day looms (Full preview available on the NEWsquawk Research Suite). That said, Friday’s polls pointed to a slight narrowing and Cable ends into the EU close with intraday losses, but more on the back of short-covering heading into a potentially risk-packed end-week - which will also see the last batch of weekend polls ahead of December 12th. GBP/USD resides around the top of its 1.2896-3166 weekly range having surpassed its 100 WMA (1.3050), 200 DMA (1.3098) and a bunch of psychological levels to the upside before stopping short of a Fib around 1.3168. Ahead of the election, YouGov will be releasing its final MRP model on December 10th at 2200GMT. Elsewhere, the EUR largely moved at the whim of the Buck throughout the week, with the pair poised to end the session with modest weekly gains, having fluctuated within weekly parameters of 1.1000-1.1162 and below its 21 WMA and DMA at 1.1072 and 1.1043 respectively. Looking ahead next week sees ECB President Lagarde’s first monetary policy meeting and the German ZEW survey.

* NZD, AUD, JPY: A spectacular week for antipodeans, more-so the Kiwi with the currency poised for weekly gains of over 1.0% with initial impetus derived from glowing Q3 NZ terms of trade data, and with a further boost received by RBNZ’s capital requirement hike and upbeat reiterations from RBNZ’s Deputy Governor Bascand who took note of strong commodity prices supporting the New Zealand economy, while adding that fiscal stimulus could increase the country’s growth next year. NZD/USD advanced above the 0.6500 mark and continued north of its 200 DMA (0.6540) having clocked in a weekly band of 0.6424-6574. Meanwhile, the Aussie initially firmed after the RBA left its Cash Rate unchanged at 0.75%, as expected, and repeated that the Australian economy the gentle turning point in the economy. That said, data has since disappointed, with GDP growth slowing to 0.4% from 0.5%. Thus, the AUD failed to benefit from positive US-China trade headlines to its full extent but is still set to close the EU session above its 21 WMA (0.6820) and towards the top of a 0.6761-6862 weekly band. Meanwhile, the JPY is poised for a week of gains, albeit more on the back of overall Dollar weakness. USD/JPY heads into the end of the EU week towards the bottom of its 108.43-109.73 weekly band, and below its 200 WMA (109.80), 100 WMA (109.63), 21 DMA (108.89) and 200 DMA (108.86).

reaction_details: • In an immediate reaction to the news that the Saudi's will continue the 400k bpd of voluntary cuts, Brent Feb' 19 futures rallied north of USD 63.85/bbl from USD 63.45/bbl
analysis_details: • For context, a WSJ report yesterday suggested that the Saudis had been threatening to increase production to its OPEC+ quota level (rather than continuing with voluntary cuts), out of frustration with the countries that had not been complying with the cuts. This raised some concerns amongst analysts, who despite knowing that the cartel had agreed to approx. 500k bpd in additional cuts, were concerned that this may be offset by the Saudis deciding not to continue with their substantial additional voluntary cuts.

subject: US EQUITY OPEN: S&P, Nasdaq and Dow Jones open ~0.8% higher after a stellar US jobs report
content:
Individual Stock Movers: 

  • Ulta Beauty (ULTA) trade over 9% higher buoyed by a strong earnings report which saw EPS beat plus a guidance update above analyst expectations
  • Tesla (TSLA) up just shy of 2% after China made Tesla cars qualify for subsidies where buyers will get as much as USD 3550 from the government
  • DocuSign (DOCU) higher by 4% at the open following its earnings where it beat on top and bottom line estimates whilst raising its FY20 forecasts higher than the street expectations
  • DR Hortin (DHI) lower by 3% after an initiation to sell from Goldman Sachs with a USD 51 price target
  • Ciena (CIEN) lower by over 4% after a downgrade to sell from neutral at UBS
analysis_details: US equities opened higher across the board following a stellar US jobs report which saw headline NFP’s print 266k above the street’s estimates for a 180k print and a better than expected wages and unemployment figures. Sectors all open in the green despite utilities which trades marginally in the red given the defensive nature of the sector. Consumer Staples, another defensive, still opened 0.2% albeit less so than other sectors. Energy lead the gains today as the sector is up over 2% on higher oil prices as OPEC affirm it is to cut production by 500k BPD. Financials trade over 1.3% higher following higher yields as markets took a flight out of quality on the key US data.

NEWsquawk Daily US Opening News - 6th December 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • European equities reside in modestly positive territory, FTSE 100 outperforms on a softer Sterling
  • China is reportedly to implement tariff waivers for some purchases of soybeans and pork from the US but has taken countermeasures against US limit on diplomats, sources state
  • OPEC+ additional 500k BPD output cuts could be split roughly 2/3 for OPEC and 1/3 for Non-OPEC, according to sources
  • In FX, GBP softened on potential profit taking, DXY trades on the firmer side and Kiwi outperforms peers thus far
  • Looking ahead, highlights include OPEC+ meeting, US and Canadian Jobs Reports, Uni. Of Michigan, Baker Hughes Rig Count, UK General Election Debate

TRADE

US National Security Advisor O'Brien suggested the sides are close on a phase 1 deal and that he spoke with Treasury Secretary Mnuchin as well as USTR Lighthizer earlier, while he added the US is monitoring Hong Kong situation closely. (Newswires)

China is reportedly to implement tariff waivers for some purchases of soybeans and pork from the US., Xinhua. Separately, China has taken countermeasures against US limit on diplomats., according to sources citing Chinese TV. (Newswires)

China Global Times tweeted that contradictory statements by US officials over the phase one deal might just be Washington testing the waters, while it also stated that trade talks remain on track citing an expert. (Newswires/Twitter)

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets were higher across the board as the recent US-China trade optimism reverberated in the region, but with gains capped as the OPEC/OPEC+ meetings stole much of the limelight and as looming US NFP jobs data kept participants tentative. ASX 200 (+0.4%) and Nikkei 225 (+0.2%) traded positively in which gold miners outperformed the broad but mostly tepid gains for Australia’s sectors, while upside in Tokyo was also limited by recent currency strength and after Household Spending contracted by the most in over 5 years. Hang Seng (+1.0%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.4%) were kept afloat after the PBoC conducted a CNY 300bln MLF operation which was larger than the prior operation of CNY 200bln and the CNY 187.5bln of maturing loans, while the trade rhetoric continued to suggest talks are going well and are on track with a phase 1 deal said to be close, although other reports were less optimistic and noted the sides were still at odds on agriculture purchases. Finally, 10yr JGBs were lower which was initially the aftermath of the prior day’s pullback amid gains in riskier assets, while prices remained subdued ahead of the December 2019 futures contract rolling over this weekend and with the BoJ’s presence in the market for JPY over 1.1tln of JGBs in 1yr-10yr maturities doing little to spur a rebound.

PBoC conducted CNY 300bln 1-year Medium-term Lending Facility operations at 3.25% vs. Prev. 3.25%. (Newswires) PBoC set USD/CNY reference rate at 7.0383 vs. Exp. 7.0368 (Prev. 7.0521)

Hong Kong Police Commissioner urged protesters to reject violence ahead of Sunday’s major demonstration from the Civil Human Rights Front which was approved by authorities. (Newswires/SCMP)

Japanese All Household Spending (Oct) M/M -11.5% vs. Exp. -9.8% (Prev. 5.5%); largest decline since April 2014. (Newswires) Japanese All Household Spending (Oct) Y/Y -5.1% vs. Exp. -3.0% (Prev. 9.5%); largest decline since March 2016.

 

GEOPOLITICS

US President Trump tweeted that the story regarding US sending 12k troops to Saudi Arabia is false and called it fake news. (Twitter)

Russia and Turkey are steadily working on a contract for a new batch of Russian S-400 missile defence systems, according to IFX citing a senior Russian official. (Newswires) US

US House Speaker Pelosi said she doesn't think the US is heading for a shutdown, while she also commented that USMCA issues relate to workers' rights and pharmaceuticals. In related news, Canadian Deputy PM Freeland said USMCA signatories face difficult challenge to get the treaty ratified by US. (Newswires)

UK/EU

UK Election Britain Elects/New Stateman tracker of polls showed Conservatives at 42.4% (+0.1), Labour 32.8% (+1.4), Lib Dems 13.1% (-1.0) and Brexit Party 3.4% (-0.4). (Newswires)

 

EQUITIES

Major European bourses (Euro Stoxx 50 +0.4%) are in the green, as the region benefits from overnight US/China trade tailwinds, although the onset of pre-NFP caution is keeping trade subdued. As a reminder, US President Trump yesterday said that “something” could happen with regards to tariffs on December 15th, although it is not being discussed yet, but the US is holding discussions with China which are going well. The FTSE 100 (+0.7%) outperforms its peers as Sterling pulls back from recent highs. The DAX (+0.3%) is comparatively muted, after German industrial data this morning disappointed which suggests “that the German economy is continuing to flirt with stagnation and contraction in the final quarter of the year”, according to ING. The CAC 40 (+0.5%) continues to brush off ongoing strikes that have brought much of the country to a standstill. Sectors are all in the green, with the more risk sensitive sectors the outperformers; Tech (+0.8%) and Consumer Discretionary (+0.7%) are the current leaders, while Health Care (+0.1%), Utilities (+0.2%) and Telecoms (+0.1%). In terms of individual movers; Ipsen (-20.6%) shares tanked after the Co. partially delayed two studies into Palovarotene. Swiss Re (+2.6%) was buoyed on the news that the Co. is to sell its Reassure unit to Phoenix Group (+0.3%) in a cash and stock deal valued at GBP 3.2bln. In terms of earnings, Carl Zeiss (-6.5%) is under pressure despite solid gains in FY19 revenue and EBIT; traders were reportedly disappointed by margin targets and, following a run of recent strong earnings reports. Finally, in broker moves, upgrades for Lufthansa (+1.3%), Ryan Air (+1.3%) and Pernod Ricard (+0.7%) saw their respective shares supported, while downgrades for Sanofi (-0.6%), Siemens Healthineers (-1.9%) and Petrofac (-1.6%) saw their shares under pressure.

FX

DXY, CAD - The broad Dollar and index trades on a firmer footing heading into the much-anticipated US Labour market data (albeit more on the back of a softer GBP – see below), with forecasts for 180k jobs to be added in November, slightly ahead of 3-,6- and 12-month trends rates (Full preview available on the NEWsquawk research suite). DXY remains in the green at time of writing, and just above the middle of the current 97.36-44 intraday band ahead of the main event. Alongside this, Canada will also be releasing its respective jobs report, with the region expected to have added 10k jobs in November. USD/CAD trades at the whim of energy prices thus far as the OPEC+ cartel convenes. The pair resides just under the 1.3200 mark with USD 750mln of options expiring between strikes at 1.3165-75. In terms of pertinent levels, the pair sees its 21 WMA at 1.3212, 100 WMA at 1.3118 and its 200 WMA at 1.3080.

GBP, JPY, EUR - Sterling trades softer on the day with little fresh fundamental news-flow, although participants could be cashing in on the impressive gains seen throughout the week ahead of the last batch of weekend polling prior to the election. In terms of the latest, Britain Elects/New Stateman tracker of polls points to a strong lead for the Tories over Labour, but the spread has modestly narrowed. Meanwhile, Ipsos Mori’s poll also showed a slight narrowing in Tory’s lead over Labour. Participants remain on the lookout for the Panelbase poll which may be released today. GBP/USD retains a 1.31+ status at time of writing, but off its current daily and weekly high of 1.3166 (vs. intraday low of 1.3111), with touted support at 1.3080 should it break the 1.3100 psychological mark. That said, today’s options expiries include ~GBP 750mln at strike 1.3100 which could influence price action, contingent on the NFP numbers Stateside and any UK election polling released in the interim. Meanwhile, the JPY remains supported by the GBP/JPY cross which dipped below 142.50 in early trade, although the Sterling softness did provide the Dollar with some impetus and thus keeps USD/JPY at bay just above the 108.50 as the pair bides its time ahead of the US labour market report. Finally, EUR/USD saw downside amid the aforementioned Dollar strength in early EU trade, with the pair dipping below the 1.1100 mark to a low of around 1.1095 ahead of touted support at 1.1090. EUR/USD options today see EUR 1.1bln expiring between 1.1095-1.1100 and EUR 1.3bln around 1.1120-25 - again, options’ influence today is contingent on the US jobs numbers.

NZD, AUD - Both modestly firmer in early EU trade in a continuation of support seen during the back end of yesterday’s session, and with potential buoyancy from reports that China could be implementing tariff waivers for some purchases of soybeans and pork; a possible olive branch to the US. The Kiwi outperforms its Aussie counterpart on the back of optimistic reiterations from RBNZ’s Deputy Governor, who touched upon persisting downside risk appearing to be more balance now. Bascand also took note of strong commodity prices supporting the New Zealand economy, while adding that fiscal stimulus could increase the country’s growth next year. NZD/USD took out yesterday high (0.6562) and resides just off session highs of 0.6573 (vs. low 0.6541) at the time of writing. Meanwhile, its Aussie counterpart inches towards the 0.6850 mark having found an intraday base at 0.6830 and with around AUD 1.0bln in options expiring at strike 0.6835.

RBNZ Deputy Governor Bascand reiterated the economy looks close to turning point and that downside risks persist but are more balanced, while he added strong commodity prices are supporting the economy and fiscal stimulus could boost growth next year. (Newswires)

Notable FX Expiries:

-        EUR/USD: 1.1040-50 (1.8BLN), 1.1075 (900M),1.1095-1.1100 (1.1BLN) 1.1120-25 (1.3BLN)

-        GBP/USD: 1.3100 (753M), 1.3170 (350M), 1.3200 (320M)

-        AUD/USD: 0.6835 (1BLN)

-        USD/CAD: 1.3165-75 (750M)

 

FIXED INCOME

Debt is setting up for a slower finish to a turbulent week, though it may be a holding pattern until the day’s highlight via the US jobs report (Exp. +180k). Newsflow has been comparatively quiet this morning for Europe, while Gilts are the marginal outperformer this morning but are only 20 ticks into positive territory at best. Price action occurred as sterling came under some pressure this morning threatening a test of key levels; though Gilts are yet to convincingly attain the 132.0 mark, 132.05 at best, on a lack of fundamental drivers. European bonds are overall little changed, with periphery debt ever so slightly in the red and core counterparts marginally positive, technically resistance in the Bund lies around the 172.45 mark and note above this yesterday’s high of 172.66; no significant events remain on the European slate so all eyes will be on the NFP print. Stateside, ahead of this, USTs are roughly in-line with their European counterparts as such the curve is little changed at present.

 

COMMODITIES 

Crude markets are jittery, with participants keeping their powder dry ahead of key risk events in the form of the US jobs report at 13:30 GMT and the outcome of today’s OPEC+ meeting, where a final decision on output cuts will be finalised. The complex has been relatively unresponsive to the latest headlines; consensus is for OPEC+ to agree to 500k bpd worth of additional cuts, which could be split 2/3 for OPEC and 1/3 for Non-OPEC, according to the latest sources. This is relatively in-line with the thinking yesterday that the split would 350k bpd to 150k bpd in cuts for OPEC and Non-OPEC countries respectively. However, ING flag the risk of potential market disappointment; “the key question is whether these reported cuts will actually reflect fresh cuts, and so help to reduce the surplus in 1Q20, or whether they will just formalise the over-compliance that we have seen from the group as a whole (thanks to Saudi Arabia)”. The latter would constitute disappointment, the analysts believe. Elsewhere, Russia, who had expressed reluctance to agree to deeper cuts, appear to have been brought on side by having their request to remove the condensate portion of its output removed from its production cut quotas, meaning roughly 800k bpd in Russian output will not be subject to any output cuts. Elsewhere, Angola reportedly stormed out of the talks in protest to the consensus for deeper cuts and now wants to quit the cartel. Furthermore, yesterday’s post meeting press conference was cancelled, with talks reportedly dragging on due to issues with Iraq, although the Iraqi Oil Minister has since said the country will comply with the agreed cuts. Today’s OPEC+ meeting has already begun, with a press conference pencilled in for 13:00 GMT, although, as is usually the case with OPEC+, timings are more a guideline. WTI and Brent front month contracts sees losses as US participants enter the market with the former dipping below USD 58/bbl and the latter eyeing USD 63/bbl. In terms of metals, copper and gold are subdued ahead of NFP, the latter consolidating around the USD 1475/oz mark, although with a slight downwards bias on account of the market’s more constructive risk tone.

 

OPEC+ additional 500k BPD output cuts could be split roughly 2/3 for OPEC and 1/3 for Non-OPEC, according to sources. (Newswires) Roughly in-line with yesterdays delegates reports

Iranaian Oil Minister says in the next 3 or 4 months we will have a extraordinary OPEC meeting, and around half a million of new cuts has been agreed to. (Twitter)

Russia Energy Minister Novak commented the quota split is to be decided on Friday and confirmed that gas condensate output of 760k BPD is now excluded from Russia's quota. (Newswires)

Saudi Oil Minister Abdulaziz said we cannot say we have an agreement until we meet Non-OPEC, while other reports noted that Saudi Arabia's new target is likely to be above 10.1mln bpd vs. current 10.31mln bpd citing delegates. (Newswires)

Kuwait Oil Minister stated OPEC is in agreement but did not comment on what was agreed, although several twitter reports suggested a quota adjustment of 500k bpd was agreed in principle although the details still need to be discussed with OPEC+. (Newswires/Twitter)

subject: OPEC+ agrees to 500k BPD cut, according to sources
NEWsquawk EU Mid Session: Pre-NFP lull as OPEC+ mull cut allocations - 6th December 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

EQUITIES

Major European bourses (Euro Stoxx 50 +0.4%) are in the green, as the region benefits from overnight US/China trade tailwinds, although the onset of pre-NFP caution is keeping trade subdued. As a reminder, US President Trump yesterday said that “something” could happen with regards to tariffs on December 15th, although it is not being discussed yet, but the US is holding discussions with China which are going well. The FTSE 100 (+0.7%) outperforms its peers as Sterling pulls back from recent highs. The DAX (+0.3%) is comparatively muted, after German industrial data this morning disappointed which suggests “that the German economy is continuing to flirt with stagnation and contraction in the final quarter of the year”, according to ING. The CAC 40 (+0.5%) continues to brush off ongoing strikes that have brought much of the country to a standstill. Sectors are all in the green, with the more risk sensitive sectors the outperformers; Tech (+0.8%) and Consumer Discretionary (+0.7%) are the current leaders, while Health Care (+0.1%), Utilities (+0.2%) and Telecoms (+0.1%). In terms of individual movers; Ipsen (-20.6%) shares tanked after the Co. partially delayed two studies into Palovarotene. Swiss Re (+2.6%) was buoyed on the news that the Co. is to sell its Reassure unit to Phoenix Group (+0.3%) in a cash and stock deal valued at GBP 3.2bln. In terms of earnings, Carl Zeiss (-6.5%) is under pressure despite solid gains in FY19 revenue and EBIT; traders were reportedly disappointed by margin targets and, following a run of recent strong earnings reports. Finally, in broker moves, upgrades for Lufthansa (+1.3%), Ryan Air (+1.3%) and Pernod Ricard (+0.7%) saw their respective shares supported, while downgrades for Sanofi (-0.6%), Siemens Healthineers (-1.9%) and Petrofac (-1.6%) saw their shares under pressure.

FX

DXY, CAD - The broad Dollar and index trades on a firmer footing heading into the much-anticipated US Labour market data (albeit more on the back of a softer GBP – see below), with forecasts for 180k jobs to be added in November, slightly ahead of 3-,6- and 12-month trends rates (Full preview available on the NEWsquawk research suite). DXY remains in the green at time of writing, and just above the middle of the current 97.36-44 intraday band ahead of the main event. Alongside this, Canada will also be releasing its respective jobs report, with the region expected to have added 10k jobs in November. USD/CAD trades at the whim of energy prices thus far as the OPEC+ cartel convenes. The pair resides just under the 1.3200 mark with USD 750mln of options expiring between strikes at 1.3165-75. In terms of pertinent levels, the pair sees its 21 WMA at 1.3212, 100 WMA at 1.3118 and its 200 WMA at 1.3080.

GBP, JPY, EUR - Sterling trades softer on the day with little fresh fundamental news-flow, although participants could be cashing in on the impressive gains seen throughout the week ahead of the last batch of weekend polling prior to the election. In terms of the latest, Britain Elects/New Stateman tracker of polls points to a strong lead for the Tories over Labour, but the spread has modestly narrowed. Meanwhile, Ipsos Mori’s poll also showed a slight narrowing in Tory’s lead over Labour. Participants remain on the lookout for the Panelbase poll which may be released today. GBP/USD retains a 1.31+ status at time of writing, but off its current daily and weekly high of 1.3166 (vs. intraday low of 1.3111), with touted support at 1.3080 should it break the 1.3100 psychological mark. That said, today’s options expiries include ~GBP 750mln at strike 1.3100 which could influence price action, contingent on the NFP numbers Stateside and any UK election polling released in the interim. Meanwhile, the JPY remains supported by the GBP/JPY cross which dipped below 142.50 in early trade, although the Sterling softness did provide the Dollar with some impetus and thus keeps USD/JPY at bay just above the 108.50 as the pair bides its time ahead of the US labour market report. Finally, EUR/USD saw downside amid the aforementioned Dollar strength in early EU trade, with the pair dipping below the 1.1100 mark to a low of around 1.1095 ahead of touted support at 1.1090. EUR/USD options today see EUR 1.1bln expiring between 1.1095-1.1100 and EUR 1.3bln around 1.1120-25 - again, options’ influence today is contingent on the US jobs numbers.

NZD, AUD - Both modestly firmer in early EU trade in a continuation of support seen during the back end of yesterday’s session, and with potential buoyancy from reports that China could be implementing tariff waivers for some purchases of soybeans and pork; a possible olive branch to the US. The Kiwi outperforms its Aussie counterpart on the back of optimistic reiterations from RBNZ’s Deputy Governor, who touched upon persisting downside risk appearing to be more balance now. Bascand also took note of strong commodity prices supporting the New Zealand economy, while adding that fiscal stimulus could increase the country’s growth next year. NZD/USD took out yesterday high (0.6562) and resides just off session highs of 0.6573 (vs. low 0.6541) at the time of writing. Meanwhile, its Aussie counterpart inches towards the 0.6850 mark having found an intraday base at 0.6830 and with around AUD 1.0bln in options expiring at strike 0.6835.

FIXED INCOME

Debt is setting up for a slower finish to a turbulent week, though it may be a holding pattern until the day’s highlight via the US jobs report (Exp. +180k). Newsflow has been comparatively quiet this morning for Europe, while Gilts are the marginal outperformer this morning but are only 20 ticks into positive territory at best. Price action occurred as sterling came under some pressure this morning threatening a test of key levels; though Gilts are yet to convincingly attain the 132.0 mark, 132.05 at best, on a lack of fundamental drivers. European bonds are overall little changed, with periphery debt ever so slightly in the red and core counterparts marginally positive, technically resistance in the Bund lies around the 172.45 mark and note above this yesterday’s high of 172.66; no significant events remain on the European slate so all eyes will be on the NFP print. Stateside, ahead of this, USTs are roughly in-line with their European counterparts as such the curve is little changed at present.

COMMODITIES

However, ING flag the risk of potential market disappointment; “the key question is whether these reported cuts will actually reflect fresh cuts, and so help to reduce the surplus in 1Q20, or whether they will just formalise the over-compliance that we have seen from the group as a whole (thanks to Saudi Arabia)”. The latter would constitute disappointment, the analysts believe. Elsewhere, Russia, who had expressed reluctance to agree to deeper cuts, appear to have been brought on side by having their request to remove the condensate portion of its output removed from its production cut quotas, meaning roughly 800k bpd in Russian output will not be subject to any output cuts. Elsewhere, Angola reportedly stormed out of the talks in protest to the consensus for deeper cuts and now wants to quit the cartel. Furthermore, yesterday’s post meeting press conference was cancelled, with talks reportedly dragging on due to issues with Iraq, although the Iraqi Oil Minister has since said the country will comply with the agreed cuts. Today’s OPEC+ meeting has already begun, with a press conference pencilled in for 13:00 GMT, although, as is usually the case with OPEC+, timings are more a guideline. WTI and Brent front month contracts sees losses as US participants enter the market with the former dipping below USD 58/bbl and the latter eyeing USD 63/bbl. In terms of metals, copper and gold are subdued ahead of NFP, the latter consolidating around the USD 1475/oz mark, although with a slight downwards bias on account of the market’s more constructive risk tone.

**EUROPEAN EQUITY COVERAGE WILL ONLY COVER COMPANIES IN THE STOXX 600 OR COMPANIES OF SYSTEMIC IMPORTANCE TO PARTICULAR SECTORS**

6th December 2019

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700GMT/0100CST recapping all of the   overnight equity news

From 0700GMT/0100CST all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715GMT/0115CST.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750GMT/0150CST recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715GMT/0115CST ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian equity markets were higher across the board as the recent US-China trade optimism reverberated in the region, but with gains capped as the OPEC/OPEC+ meetings stole much of the limelight and as looming US NFP jobs data kept participants tentative. ASX 200 (+0.4%) and Nikkei 225 (+0.3%) traded positive in which gold miners outperformed the broad but mostly tepid gains for Australia’s sectors, while upside in Tokyo was also limited by recent currency strength and after Household Spending contracted by the most in over 5 years. Hang Seng (+0.7%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.1%) were kept afloat after the PBoC conducted a CNY 300bln MLF operation which was larger than the prior operation of CNY 200bln and the CNY 187.5bln of maturing loans, while the trade rhetoric continued to suggest talks are going well and are on track with a phase 1 deal said to be close, although other reports were less optimistic and noted the sides were still at odds on agriculture purchases.

MTU AERO ENGINES (MTX GY) INITIATED WITH OVERWEIGHT AT BARCLAYS

CAC

OTHER FRENCH COMPANIES

BROKER MOVES

subject: NEWsquawk Daily European Opening News - 6th December 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • Asian equity markets were higher as the recent US-China trade optimism reverberated in the region, but with gains capped by uncertainty from OPEC and ahead of key US data
  • US President Trump said something could happen with regards to tariffs on December 15th but we are not discussing that yet
  • OPEC delegates suggested a 350k cut for OPEC and a 150k cut Russia and Non-OPEC
  • OPEC official announced the press conference was cancelled for Thursday and sources noted the OPEC meeting was prolonged over issues including Iraq
  • Looking ahead, highlights include German Industrial Output, OPEC+ meeting, US and Canadian Jobs Reports, Uni. Of Michigan, Baker Hughes Rig Count, UK General Election Debate

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets were higher across the board as the recent US-China trade optimism reverberated in the region, but with gains capped as the OPEC/OPEC+ meetings stole much of the limelight and as looming US NFP jobs data kept participants tentative. ASX 200 (+0.4%) and Nikkei 225 (+0.3%) traded positively in which gold miners outperformed the broad but mostly tepid gains for Australia’s sectors, while upside in Tokyo was also limited by recent currency strength and after Household Spending contracted by the most in over 5 years. Hang Seng (+0.7%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.1%) were kept afloat after the PBoC conducted a CNY 300bln MLF operation which was larger than the prior operation of CNY 200bln and the CNY 187.5bln of maturing loans, while the trade rhetoric continued to suggest talks are going well and are on track with a phase 1 deal said to be close, although other reports were less optimistic and noted the sides were still at odds on agriculture purchases. Finally, 10yr JGBs were lower which was initially the aftermath of the prior day’s pullback amid gains in riskier assets, while prices remained subdued ahead of the December 2019 futures contract rolling over this weekend and with the BoJ’s presence in the market for JPY over 1.1tln of JGBs in 1yr-10yr maturities doing little to spur a rebound.

PBoC conducted CNY 300bln 1-year Medium-term Lending Facility operations at 3.25% vs. Prev. 3.25%. (Newswires) PBoC set USD/CNY reference rate at 7.0383 vs. Exp. 7.0368 (Prev. 7.0521)

US President Trump said something could happen with regards to tariffs on December 15th but we are not discussing that yet and that the US is holding discussions with China which are going well, while he also commented the US may do trade related things to countries who are not contributing enough to NATO. (Newswires)

US National Security Advisor O'Brien suggested the sides are close on a phase 1 deal and that he spoke with Treasury Secretary Mnuchin as well as USTR Lighthizer earlier, while he added the US is monitoring Hong Kong situation closely. (Newswires)

China reportedly provided official reassurance that negotiations with the US remain on track. In related news, China Global Times tweeted that contradictory statements by US officials over the phase one deal might just be Washington testing the waters, while it also stated that trade talks remain on track citing an expert. (Newswires/Twitter)

Hong Kong Police Commissioner urged protesters to reject violence ahead of Sunday’s major demonstration from the Civil Human Rights Front which was approved by authorities. (Newswires/SCMP)

Japanese All Household Spending (Oct) M/M -11.5% vs. Exp. -9.8% (Prev. 5.5%); largest decline since April 2014. (Newswires) Japanese All Household Spending (Oct) Y/Y -5.1% vs. Exp. -3.0% (Prev. 9.5%); largest decline since March 2016.

UK/EU

UK Election Britain Elects/New Stateman tracker of polls showed Conservatives at 42.4% (+0.1), Labour 32.8% (+1.4), Lib Dems 13.1% (-1.0) and Brexit Party 3.4% (-0.4). (Newswires)

 

FX

DXY was subdued after a continuation of the December retreat to below the 97.50 level with the greenback eyeing a 7th consecutive daily loss as it consolidated at the lowest in just over a month, with participants now looking ahead to the US jobs data. This has kept EUR/USD and GBP/USD above the recently reclaimed 1.1100 and 1.3150 levels respectively, with the latter having been underpinned as polls pointed to a strong lead for the Conservatives including the Britain Elects poll tracker which showed the ruling party remains nearly 10 points ahead of Labour a week away from the elections, despite a slight narrowing in the margin. Elsewhere, USD/JPY was subdued by the recent dollar woes, while antipodeans edged marginal gains on the mostly positive risk appetite and firmer PBoC reference rate, as well as comments from RBNZ Deputy Governor Bascand who reiterated that the economy looks close to a turning point.

RBNZ Deputy Governor Bascand reiterated the economy looks close to turning point and that downside risks persist but are more balanced, while he added strong commodity prices are supporting the economy and fiscal stimulus could boost growth next year. (Newswires)

Canadian PM Trudeau promised tax cuts, housing investment and infrastructure, while he will pursue a sensible fiscal plan and will work to get Canadian resources to new markets as well as support workers in the natural resources sector. (Newswires) 

COMMODITIES

Commodities were uneventful overnight with WTI crude futures subdued after its recent pullback from resistance at the USD 59.00/bbl level and as participants await the official announcement from OPEC in which the group is said to have reached an agreement in principal for an additional 500k bpd cut although still have to work out the details with Non-OPEC producers at today’s meeting. In addition, OPEC had cancelled yesterday’s press conference as the meeting was prolonged reportedly due to issues with Iraq, while members agreed to exclude numbers on gas condensate volumes on Russia and all Non-OPEC output which is used to determine the baseline for cuts and in turn, resulted to some mild pressure for oil. Elsewhere, gold flatlined with participants await the upcoming key US jobs numbers and copper only marginally benefitted from the tepid gains in stocks.

OPEC official announced the press conference was cancelled for Thursday and sources noted the OPEC meeting was prolonged over issues including Iraq. In related news, Angola reportedly left the meeting and wants to quit while delegates suggested a 350k cut for OPEC and a 150k cut Russia and Non-OPEC. (Newswires/Twitter/Energy Intel) OPEC+ plus committee reportedly recommended excluding numbers on gas condensate on Russian crude output and all Non-OPEC members, in which all OPEC+ members reportedly agreed with the recommendation. Furthermore, Russia Energy Minister Novak commented the quota split is to be decided on Friday and confirmed that gas condensate output of 760k BPD is now excluded from Russia's quota. (Newswires)

Saudi Oil Minister Abdulaziz said we cannot say we have an agreement until we meet Non-OPEC, while other reports noted that Saudi Arabia's new target is likely to be above 10.1mln bpd vs. current 10.31mln bpd citing delegates. (Newswires)

Kuwait Oil Minister stated OPEC is in agreement but did not comment on what was agreed, although several twitter reports suggested a quota adjustment of 500k bpd was agreed in principle although the details still need to be discussed with OPEC+. (Newswires/Twitter)

GEOPOLITICS

US President Trump tweeted that the story regarding US sending 12k troops to Saudi Arabia is false and called it fake news, while Defence Secretary Esper had earlier commented that the US is not considering sending 14k additional troops to the Middle East at this time. (Newswires) Iran is determined to continue its ballistic missile programme the country said in a letter to the UN, while it was also reported that Iran is reportedly working on nuclear-capable missiles according to European Powers. (AFP)

US 

T-notes continued to sell-off on Thursday, albeit less pronounced than Wednesday, with the prior session’s trade optimism reducing demand for the haven. Prices found some support close to the US cash equity open, where major equity bourses were offered in lack of immediate news flow, with some desks noting profit taking, bringing the TPLEX off lows into settlement, where the curve steepened slightly, mainly in the front to belly; the 2-year yield was little changed, 5-year yield up by 1.8bps and the 10- and 30-year yields both up by 1.5bps. T-note (z0) futures settled 3 ticks lower at 129-10.

US House Speaker Pelosi said she doesn't think the US is heading for a shutdown, while she also commented that USMCA issues relate to workers' rights and pharmaceuticals. In related news, Canadian Deputy PM Freeland said USMCA signatories face difficult challenge to get the treaty ratified by US. (Newswires)

ASIA-PAC MARKET WRAP: Asia stocks edged mild gains as trade optimism reverberated, but with gains capped ahead of NFPs
content: Asia equity markets were higher across the board as the recent US-China trade optimism reverberated in the region, but with gains capped as the OPEC/OPEC+ meetings stole much of the limelight and as looming US NFP jobs data kept participants tentative. ASX 200 (+0.4%) and Nikkei 225 (+0.3%) traded positive in which gold miners outperformed the broad but mostly tepid gains for Australia’s sectors, while upside in Tokyo was also limited by recent currency strength and after Household Spending contracted by the most in over 5 years. Hang Seng (+0.7%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.1%) were kept afloat after the PBoC conducted a CNY 300bln MLF operation which was larger than the prior operation of CNY 200bln and the CNY 187.5bln of maturing loans, while the trade rhetoric continued to suggest talks are going well and are on track with a phase 1 deal said to be close, although other reports were less optimistic and noted the sides were still at odds on agriculture purchases. Finally, 10yr JGBs were lower which was initially the aftermath of the prior day’s pullback amid gains in riskier assets, while prices remained subdued ahead of the December 2019 futures contract rolling over this weekend and with the BoJ’s presence in the market for JPY over 1.1tln of JGBs in 1yr-10yr maturities doing little to spur a rebound.

ASIA-PAC MID-SESSION UPDATE: Asia stocks edge mild gains as trade optimism reverberates, but with gains capped ahead of NFPs
content:
Asia equity markets are mostly higher as sentiment continues to reflect the recent US-China trade optimism but with gains capped as the OPEC/OPEC+ meetings steal some of the limelight and with looming Non-Farm Payrolls data keeping participants tentative. ASX 200 (+0.2%) and Nikkei 225 (+0.2%) trade positive with gold miners outperforming the broad but mostly tepid gains across Australia’s sectors, while upside in Tokyo is also limited by recent currency strength and after Household Spending contracted by the most in over 5 years. Hang Seng (+0.9%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.1%) are kept afloat after the PBoC conducted a CNY 300bln MLF operation which was larger than the prior operation of CNY 200bln and the CNY 187.5bln of maturing loans, while the trade rhetoric continues to suggest talks are going well with the sides close to a phase 1 deal, although other reports were less optimistic and noted the sides were still at odds on agriculture purchases.

In FX markets, the DXY is subdued after a continuation of the December retreat to below the 97.50 level with the greenback eyeing a 7th consecutive loss as it consolidates at the lowest in just over a month, with participants now looking ahead to the US jobs data. This has kept EUR/USD and GBP/USD above the recently reclaimed 1.1100 and 1.3150 levels respectively, with the latter having been underpinned as polls continue point to a strong lead for the Conservatives including the Britain Elects poll tracker which showed the ruling party remains nearly 10 points ahead of Labour a week away from the elections, despite a slight narrowing in the margin. Elsewhere, USD/JPY is subdued by the recent dollar woes, while antipodeans edge marginal gains on the mostly positive risk appetite and firmer PBoC reference rate, as well as comments from RBNZ Deputy Governor Bascand who reiterated that the economy looks close to a turning point.

Finally, 10yr JGBs are lower which was mainly a function of the prior day’s after-hours decline amid the gains in riskier assets, although downside has been stemmed amid the BoJ presence in the market for JPY over 1.1tln of JGBs in 1yr-10yr maturities and with the December 2019 futures contract rolling over this weekend.
